captions.text:
[Ben Quilty] Well, I was asked to go and be the official
Australian War Artist and it's fun, funny how

the concept of it is very foreign and its
something that I'd never have considered

but I couldn't possibly say no to it. Being
an artist for me its all about experience

and that experience then feeds into the studio
practice and, and I couldn't have envisaged

a more extreme experience then going into Afghanistan
or going into any war zone.
[Sound of helicopters and fierce wind]

When I got to Afghanistan I was very aware that I,
I didn't want to be in anyone's way that I

wanted to, to sort of slot quietly into the
background and, and um, observe what was happening

simply because I had no idea what was going
to happen and I thought I've got to get in

there and be quiet, listen and watch and,
and collect information, but very quickly I

became engaged with the guys and girls I wanted
to know what they were feeling, um how they

are surviving emotionally and physically,
you know really the basics of humanity, life

and death and right there in your face the
biggest themes that an artist could ever imagine,

right there and it became pretty obvious that
the best way for me to do that would be to

get them to sit for me and to make work about
them as they tell their story to me of these
incredible experiences.

The experience of
getting these guys to sit, sit for me naked

was cathartic in a way for me and for them
because, for them it was a way of talking

about their experiences, I asked them a lot
of questions during the sitting about, you

know the smell and the sound and the heat
and the dust and the cold and the emotion

and, all of them in some sense, I think, felt
that I made portraits of them the way they

felt, rather than the way they looked or heroic
portraits of soldiers it was about the emotion

of being there ah, and it is a very emotional
place to be the, the spikes of um, testosterone

and adrenaline and, and fear and sadness and
mateship and friendship and, everything that

sort of, all the human condition in an extreme
version. Air Commodore John Oddy stood up and

said I, I, it's very confronting you've made
me look exactly the way I feel and for me
that, that's a successful painting.
I have always been interested in humans so

I wasn't as interested in the machinary of
war or the actual, physical battle because

I also couldn't get to that point, there's
no frontline, there's no frontline in Afghanistan
you sort of have to tread around the landmines and IED's and and live with the troops

and sort of experience the pressure that they're
under every day, every minute and, um this

constant threat and, and, and I sort of naturally
became interested in how you, how they cope

with that threat and how they cope with that
pressure and they're very young, often very

young people doing something extraordinary,
ahm, so I was instantly drawn to that um,

and to tell that story, involve them coming
to me after Afghanistan and in Afghanistan

and making work about them. PTSD became one
part of the show because that's what's happened

in every single war zone that Australia's
been involved in, its one part of, of that

war, but in, through post-traumatic stress
disorder there's also to hope, you know these

guys are learning with each other how to cope,
how to survive it, how to beat PTSD and how

to move forward um and how to, in a way, warn
their young friends who going to follow in

their footsteps in Afghanistan about the pitfalls
and dangers and how to cope. So that was one

other part of the show that was inevitable
when you look closely at the young people

who are there, young and old people who are
in Afghanistan on our behalf.
In, inside Khandahar the first night we were there

when I was rocketed
three times, it's one of those dark, dark, feelings

that overwhelmed me, in my bunk that night
I thought what am I doing here, I don't want

to be here, this is the noisiest, noisiest
place I've ever been, thundering, thundering

noise of massive diesel generators and airplanes
landing and cars and sirens all night, um

on the 24 hour rotation of aircraft hovering
above Afghanistan to pull in, to supply air

support whenever it's needed, so it means
it's just a constant drone in that city, in

that town, and then rockets coming in from the
outside, its surreal this the biggest build

up of military might anywhere in the world
at one point right in that spot and they're

still causing havoc by firing rockets over
the fence from a kilometre out and causing

absolute chaos and I know I had complete breakdown
in my mind that night and then woke up the

next morning and really thought these people
here now have a story to tell, these people

here are dealing with this, all the young
guys that I'd spent that night with were there

for eight months, they'd done three months,
they all laugh off the threat of rockets as

this constant saying that "you're more likely
to be hit by a Sydney bus than by a rocket

in Khandahar" which is crap, absolute crap
but I completely got it, I understood the humour,

the humour is there so that they can move
forward do their jobs, day, after day, after

day, for eight months at a time um, and it's
pretty powerful thing, to start considering

when I was there how I would then make work
about their experience.

Being in Afghanistan one of the things that hit me, that was sort
of most, um, really emotional sort of a feeling

was to feel a part of these young people's
lives and, and that I suddenly had thousands

of young Australians who are heavily armed,
who really seriously made me feel like they

were there to protect me and half of them
were half my age and they were seriously engaged

in caring for me and that's a overwhelming
feeling. Um, and then to come back and feel

like I have told part of their story, I know
that they they'll, a lot of them will do anything

for me for the rest of my life which is mindblowing,
um, humbling and, um, ah, there is not much

I can say about it, it's just ah, an incredible
feeing to be part of their lives.

If you walk into this exhibition I hope that
you will get more of a sense of what it is

like to be in Afghanistan, to more than just
what it looks like but what it feels like,

what it smells like and what it is like to
survive an experience like that.
